Description: Two grotesque figures from the rim of a pottery vessel. Each is a male figure with hairy form-fitting clothing, standing with his arms by his sides. The heads are proportionately large, and bearded; the features (eyes, nose and teeth-filled mouth) of great size. Each figure wears an amulet on a double string round the neck. The legs are largely lost. One-piece mould. Pale-buff marl clay with many small dark inclusions. Thin yellow-brown vitreous glaze on the outside.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased: Greville J. Chester. Acquired in Alexandria. Registration nos. 1878,1217.39 & 40 are two non-joining fragments of a cylindrical pot with a plain rim, to which are applied two (39) and one (40) separately moulded figures, perhaps monks or hermits in 'hair-shirts'. They are derived from the same archetype. Presumably there were others attached to the pot, encircling it. Late Roman or, more probably, early Arab period, about the seventh century AD.
